title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence and corruption in those regions. Additionally, drug trafficking in transit countries like Central America and the Caribbean contributes to instability. Drug trafficking is a significant issue in countries like Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and the Caribbean, posing threats to law enforcement, political institutions, and citizen security. In Mexico, drug-related violence is increasing, with a significant number of deaths reported in 2008. Organized criminal networks in Mexico also traffic women and girls into the United States for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups in the Western Hemisphere are also a concern. Extremist groups in the Western Hemisphere, such as FARC and Hezbollah, use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008 totaled $11.3 billion. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policy on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, drug interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. The impact of various initiatives in curbing drug production and trafficking will be evaluated. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess technology deployment against drug cartels, curb chemical precursor trafficking, evaluate US drug certification process, analyze population's demand for drugs, review prevention and treatment programs, and study factors driving drug consumption in the US. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will evaluate US policies on illicit drugs, assess international support for drug control, and review indicators of success in drug control policy. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will consult with various stakeholders to review and improve drug control policies, and submit a report to relevant committees within 12 months of its first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a detailed report to relevant committees containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions within 12 months of its first meeting. The report required under subsection (b) must be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Members serve for the duration of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, consisting of ten members appointed by various leaders, must hold an initial meeting within 60 days to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review. Six members form a quorum, and members receive travel expenses as per regulations while performing Commission services. The Commission, consisting of ten members appointed by various leaders, must hold an initial meeting within 60 days to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review. Six members form a quorum, and members receive travel expenses as per regulations while performing Commission services. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission can hold meetings as needed, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government agencies to fulfill its duties. The Chairperson must make written requests for access when required. The General Services Administration provides office space and administrative support for the Commission's activities. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. The Commission has the authority to enter into contracts, leases, or legal agreements for its activities, which cannot extend beyond the termination date of the Commission. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may appoint additional personnel without following certain regulations, but their pay cannot exceed a specified limit. The Executive Director of the Commission may procure temporary services and detail government employees to assist in carrying out duties without affecting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
